Below it are the words "family planning", "feminine hygiene", "feminine protection" and "sanitary protection"Aeuphemismis a generally innocuous word or expression used in place of one that may be foundProfanityoffensiveor suggest something unpleasant.cite dictionaryhttp://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/euphemismEuphemismWebster's Online DictionarySome euphemisms are intended to amuse; while others use bland, inoffensive terms for things the user wishes to downplay. Euphemisms are used to refer toTaboo wordtaboo topics(such as disability, sex, excretion, and death) in a polite way, or to maskprofanity.cite webeuphemism (n.)http://www.etymonline.com/index.php?termEtymonline.com7 January 2014

There are threeOpposite (semantics)antonymsof euphemism:dysphemism,dysphemismcacophemism, andloaded language. Dysphemism can be either offensive or merely ironic; cacophemism is deliberately offensive. Loaded language evokes a visceral response beyond the meaning of the words.
article.heading: Etymology
article.paragraph: Euphemismcomes from theGreek languageGreekwordlanggrcεὐφημία(euphemia), meaning "the use of words of good omen", which in turn is derived from the Greek root-wordse(langgrcεὖ), "good, well" andphm() "prophetic speech; rumour, talk"., Henry George Liddell, Robert Scott,A Greek-English Lexicon, on PerseusEtymologically, theeuphemeis the opposite of theblasphemyblaspheme"evil-speaking." The termeuphemismitself was used as a euphemism by the ancient Greeks, meaning "to keep a holy silence" (speaking well by not speaking at all).cite webhttp://www.etymonline.com/index.php?term''Euphemism" Etymology[[Online Etymology Dictionary]]10 June 2015
article.heading: Formation
Phonetic modification
article.paragraph: Phonetic euphemism is used to replace profanities, giving them the intensity of a mere interjection.

list.listitem: Shortening or "clipping" the term ("Jeez" for Jesus, "What the" for "What the hell")
Mispronunciations, such as "Frak (expletive)Frak", "Frig (interjection)Frig" "What the fudge", "What the truck", "Oh my gosh", "Frickin", "Darn", "Oh, shoot", "Be-yotch", etc.

Using the first letter ("SOB", "What the eff", "BS"). Sometimes, the word "word" is added after it ("F word", "S word", "B word"). Also, the letter can be phonetically respelled, for example, the word "piss" was shortened to "pee" in this way.

article.heading: Figures of speech

list.listitem: Ambiguousstatements (itfor excrement,the situationor "a girl in trouble" for pregnancy,going to the other sidefor death,do itorcome togetherin reference to aSexual intercourse#In humanssexual act,tired and emotionalfor drunkenness)
Understatements("asleep" for "dead", "drinking" for "consuming alcohol", "hurt" for "injured", etc.)
Metaphors("beat the meat", "choke the chicken", "take a dump", "drain the main vein").
Metonymy("lose a person" for "coping with a person's death", "pass away" for "die", "men's room" for "men's toilet").

article.heading: Rhetoric
article.paragraph: Euphemism may be used as aRhetorical strategiesrhetorical strategy, in which case its goal is to change theValence (psychology)valenceof a description from positive to negative.
article.heading: Slang
article.paragraph: Using a less harsh term with similar meaning. For instance, "screwed up" is a euphemism for "fucked up"; "hook-up", "we hooked up", or "laid" forsexual intercourse

There is some disagreement over whether certain terms are or are not euphemisms. For example, sometimes the phrasevisually impairedis labeled as apolitical correctnesspolitically correcteuphemism forblind. However,visual impairmentcan be a broader term, including, for example, people who have partial sight in one eye, those with uncorrectable mild to moderate poor vision, or even those who wear glasses, a group that would be excluded by the wordblind.
article.heading: Evolution
article.paragraph: Euphemisms may be formed in a number of ways.Periphrasis, orcircumlocution, is one of the most common: to "speak around" a given word,Implicatureimplyingit without saying it. Over time, circumlocutions become recognized as established euphemisms for particular words or ideas.

To alter the pronunciation or spelling of a taboo word (such as aswear word) to form a euphemism is known astaboo deformation, or "minced oath". InAmerican English, words that are unacceptable on television such asfuck, may be represented by deformations such asfreak, even in children's cartoons.cite webhttps://www.fcc.gov/guides/obscenity-indecency-and-profanityObscene, Indecent and Profane BroadcastsU.S. [[Federal Communications Commission]]FCC.gov2014-01-20https://web.archive.org/web/20131209153728/http://www.fcc.gov/guides/obscenity-indecency-and-profanity2013-12-09noSome examples ofrhyming slangmay serve the same purpose: to call a person aberksounds less offensive than to call a person acunt, thoughberkis short forBerkeley Hunt, which rhymes withcunt.http://www.collinsdictionary.com/dictionary/english/berk Collins Dictionary, definition of "berk"/"burk", retrieved 22 July 2014.

BureaucracyBureaucraciesfrequently spawn euphemisms of a more deliberate nature,doublespeakexpressions. For example, in the past the US military called contamination byRadionuclideradioactive isotopessunshine units.cite journalMcCoolW.C.1957-02-06Return of Rongelapese to their Home Island — Note by the Secretary[[United States Atomic Energy Commission]]http://worf.eh.doe.gov/ihp/chron/A43.PDF2007-11-07A practical death sentence in the Soviet Union during theGreat Purgeoften used the clause "imprisonmentwithout right to correspondence:" the person sentenced never had a chance to correspond because soon after imprisonment he would be shot.Solzhenitsyn, Alexander (1974). The Gulag Archipelago I. New York, NY: Harper Perennial. p. 6. ISBN 0-06-092103-XAs early as 1939, Nazi officialReinhard Heydrichused the termSonderbehandlung(translated into English as "special treatment") to meansummary execution, most likely by hanging, of persons who proved 'disciplinary problems' to the Nazis even before the Nazis began theHolocaustsystematic extermination of the Jews. Heinrich Himmler, aware that the word had come to be known to mean murder, replaced that euphemism with one in which Jews would be "guided" (to their deaths) through the slave-labor and extermination camps.http://www.holocaust-history.org/quick-facts/special-treatment.shtmlafter having been "evacuated" to their doom. Such was part of the superficially-innocuous formulationEndlsung der Judenfragewhich became infamous to the entire world during the Nuremberg Trials.http://www.ushmm.org/wlc/en/article.php?ModuleId=10005477

A euphemism may often devolve into a taboo word itself, through the linguistic process known aspejorationorsemantic changedescribed byW.V.O. Quine,cite bookW.V.QuineQuiddities[[Belknap Press]]198753–54and more recently dubbed the "euphemism treadmill" by Harvard professorSteven Pinker.cite newshttps://articles.baltimoresun.com/1994-04-06/news/1994096202_1_dutch-words-languageThe game of the nameBaltimore Sun1994-04-06http://pinker.wjh.harvard.edu/articles/media/1994_04_03_newyorktimes.pdf1994-04-032011-01-19For instance,Toiletis an 18th-century euphemism, replacing the older euphemismHouse-of-Office, which in turn replaced the even older euphemismsprivy-houseorbog-house.cite bookBellVicars WalkerOn Learning the English Tongue1953Faber & FaberThe Honest Jakes or Privy has graduated via Offices to the final horror of Toilet.19In the 20th century, where the wordslavatoryortoiletwere deemed inappropriate (e.g. in the United States), they were sometimes replaced withbathroomorwater closet,which in turn becamerestroom,W.C., orwashroom. TheS-wordappears to have originally been a euphemism for defecation in Pre-Germanic, as theProto-Indo-European languageProto-Indo-European root*skined-, from which it was derived, meant to cut off.cite bookRingeDonDonald RingeFrom Proto-Indo-European to Proto-GermanicOxford University Press2006978-0-19-955229-0

article.heading: In popular culture
article.paragraph: Doublespeak is a term sometimes used for deliberate euphemistic misuse of incorrect words to disguise unacceptablemeaning (linguistics)meaning, as in a "Ministry of Peace" which wages war, a "Ministry of Love" which imprisons and tortures. It is a portmanteau of the terms "newspeak" and "doublethink", which originate from George Orwell's novel1984 (book)1984.

The "Dead Parrot sketch" fromMonty Python's Flying Circuscontains an extensive list of euphemisms for death, including many cited above, referring to the deceased parrot that the character played byJohn Cleesehad purchased.

The word euphemism itself can be used as a euphemism. In the animated TV specialHalloween Is Grinch Night(SeeDr. Seuss), a child asks to go to theeuphemism, whereeuphemismis being used as a euphemism forouthouse. This euphemistic use of "euphemism" also occurred in the playWho's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?where a character requests, "Martha, will you show her where we keep the, uh, euphemism?"
In Wes Anderson's filmFantastic Mr. Fox (film)Fantastic Mr. Fox, the replacement of swear words by the word "cuss" became a humorous motif throughout the film.
InTom Hanks' web seriesElectric City (web series)Electric City, the use of profanity has been censored by the word "expletive".

InIsaac Asimov'sFoundation series, the curses of the scientistEbling Mishave all been replaced with the word "unprintable". In fact, there is only one case of his curses being referred to as such, leading some readers to mistakenly assume that the euphemism is Ebling's, rather than Asimov's. The same word has also been used in his short story "Flies (Asimov short story)Flies".
